text: THE REAL CLIMATE EMERGENCY:  Politicians around the world are being convinced that we need to reduce CO2 emissions and many of then are starting to do just that.  Let's get this straight. CO2 is not a pollutant. CO2 is essential to life on Earth. Life on Earth cannot exist with CO2 levels below 180ppm. Right now, the level of CO2 in our atmosphere is 400ppm. If it doubled to 800ppm the global temperature might rise by 1 degree, big deal! To rise another 1 degree, CO2 level would have to rise another 800ppm to 1600ppm - Unlikely and again, so what if it does!. Now, here is the BIG DEAL, If these idiots get their way, and half the CO2 concentrations down to 200ppm, living things start to die. One more little nudge and it's light out for you, me and every other living thing on Earth. Wake up sheep. This really is a climate emergency!

text:
This segment restores my faith in humanity just a little. I'm so sick of hearing the same five Alt-Right arguments all day every day. I'm so sick of being told how much of a sheep I am because I have Democratic values. It's exhausting, always having to play defense to justify my beliefs, opinions, and values 24-7, when Conservatives refuse to even acknowledge their beliefs, opinions, or values hurt people at all. >EVER<


At this point, the Alt-Right would argue with something so vague as "The sky is sometimes blue." And then back it up with facts and charts that prove that the sky has statistically never been blue, I'm the real racist for thinking it could possibly be blue, and then tell me how wanting a blue sky would kill the American economy.


I've put up with this for years now. Almost no one ever jumps in to help, and those who do are rarely of any help when their arguments usually provide more ammunition to the Conservatives. <.<


I'm just so tired.


I've had to disable my comment notifications because the only thing that I can reliably guarantee is that somehow someone somewhere will see this comment, disagree with it, and insist I personally be held accountable for every democratic beliefe that's ever been misquoted on a Fox channel for the past twenty years.


This is what the Right has devolved into.


No more rationalizing. I'm done trying to make peace with them. I'm done trying to get ANY of them to have a rational conversation.


I'm ready to just roll over these f&@#ers for 2020.


Let's make America "not-shitty" again.

text:
Ok climate change is a real thing that the democrats did not just make up but this is time time I think its taking it too far. Trump can speak for himself he's a complete idiot. But Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's approach is horrible. Im not trying to sound like a radical republican I'm saying the point of view of a non socialistic democrat. While the Green New Deal doesn't eliminate planes and cars and cows, it is a horrendous proposal for 3 main reasons. 1. It costs $93 trillion. Our GDP is $44 trillion. We couldn't sell all of our countries assets and pay for this thing. No country would be willing to give us a loan of that amount and no other country even has that much money. Its just unreasonable. 2. It crazily decreases the freedom of people and increases dependency on the government. Im not saying that declaring climate change as an emergency is socialism, im saying the Green New Deal is socialism. This is the Old Red Deal again. The Green New Deal is basically Marxism disguised in a modern form. I know government spending increases are bad and thats why spending on a wall doesn't make sense either. But this Green New Deal will drive taxes up crazy. We know from 1920's and 30's that lower taxes even for the wealthy are beneficial to the economy and that raises in taxes can turn a recession into a depression. Government spending is not good. These high taxes demotivate people to work because most of their money is taken by the government and it gives the government so much money that they use to redistribute to everyone. This dangerous cycle caused by extremely high taxes continues as the government tries to make everyone the same. But the truth in humanity is not everyone can be the same in opportunity and ability and eventually the government is going to run out of using other peoples money. This socialism turns into communism eventually. We've seen what this system does before in Russia and Cuba and Venezuela. The Green New Deal will trigger this cycle. Its the simple truth of communism that the system doesn't work and its an unrealistic utopia. It makes a bad problem worse. Again im not saying Trumps actions are proper either and I agree that climate change is important, but the Green New Deal a. k. a. Marxism is not the way to solve it.
Edit: Also climate change is a natural thing. Its been happening forever since the beginning of time. 15 years ago Al Gore said we would all be underwater in 12 years if nothing was done. I live in California and it doesn't seem like we'll be flooding anytime soon. Right now they're saying we'll all be flooded. They've been saying it since the 1990's. Before that, for the longest time, they were yelling about global cooling, that we would be thrown into a third ice age. Nobody made up climate change its a real thing, but climate has always changed.

text: Speaking of climate change, do you know that here in Belgium, where our politicians‚Äò inaction in taking actions to limit climate global warming is proverbial (they even refused to sign a EU recommandation 2 days after a massive demonstration of about 70.000 people in Brussels two months ago), well, here in Belgium, as I was saying, every Thursday for the last 6 weeks, young  people,  I mean kids the age of junior and high school have been marching for climate in Brussels and other Belgian cities. It draws thousands of school kids in the streets every week, some accompanied by their teachers ( yesterday‚Äôs march drew over 10.000 people, I think, with the presence of the young Swedish girl who had been demonstrating alone in front of the Swedish parliament since August). All of a sudden, our political class woke up, and with election coming in 4 months, every party claims to be greener than the others. France is starting to do it too. This has so far ,to my knowledge, not been relayed in international news, but I think it should. text: So all new green research goes away and we have higher emissions. (don't worry, green thinking comes back). The bigger problem, IMHO, is if a foreign power comes up with an alternative fuel tank or plane first, taking out our fuel supply would turn an entire battle group into immovable chunks of easily targeted metal.  They lighter alternative energy tanks would be free to pick off the $6.2M M1A1, or simply avoid them, to be further able to cut off food and fuel.  Use your imagination.  "Tesla Tanks" if you will.  Hydrogen cells could be refilled at lakes and rivers.  Small nuclear technology could be developed. Mobile command centers could use solar and wind.  Also, looking at Puerto Rico, we could save billions or have more people "Up" buy using some of the technology used by sail boots and yachts.  Solar panels and 2' windmills are common.  Switching to low power accessories will allow each off the grid house to run off batteries.  Certainly cheaper than the unreliable wires we run house to house now.  One woman in Florida had built a house with power, plumbing, and sewage.  This house WOULD be up and running in a near miss hurricane. The problem was that Orlando would not be able to bill, (for sewage, I think). so they made her reconnect.  But think how much faster Puerto Rico would have services if we were more green.

text:
Incredibly, I give one point of credit for Republicunt commentators comprehending the logical consistency that 
if Trump can declare emergency for X, then a Democrat could declare an emergency for Y.
Here, X = stupid dumbfuck reason (border wall), Y = real critical reason (manmade global warming).
In Republicans' mind, Y is a bad reason. Hence, a Democrat should not declare an emergency.
Therefore, by the contrapositive of the statement above, Trump should not declare an emergency for X.


Sorry, but it's very basic: a President SHOULD declare a national emergency for a GOOD reason and NOT for a bad reason.
That is NOT a logical contradiction.  It WOULD be a logical contradiction if I claimed:
P1 ="Any president should be allowed to declare a national emergency for ANY reason."
or
P2 = "No president should be allowed to declare a national emergency for ANY reason."


If I believed either P1 or P2 then it would be a contradiction for me to support emergency declaration for Y but not for X.

STOP FLYING/DRIVING for any type of entertainment, vacations, bar hopping, movies, concerts, sporting event, etc.  Movies use multiple vehicles and generators that pour CO2 Pollutants into the atmosphere, mostly because they SIT on set, IDLING!

text:
Sorry Seth old Buddy, but I am skeptical and have a right to be. You see when I was a sophomore in HS I had a since teacher that told our whole class that by the year 2000, and due to the "New Ice Age" everyone living north of Kentucky would be living in and igloo. When I told her I did not believe her she said the science was real and could not be refuted. She also disliked me for questioning her. LMAO!
   In 1993 Al Gore wrote in his manifesto on global warming that by the year 2008 all of the cities along the coasts would be partially under water due to polar ice melt. Unfortunately for all the AL and his band of chicken little types this did not happen. When asked by a reporter in 2018 (10 years later) why this has not happened yet, he replied, "Well......, It just hasn't happened yet."
   A few years ago and before the words "climate change" was the new buzzword for these scares that have not happened, they all used the words "global warming." It was good old Julian Assange and his merry band at Wikileaks who hacked into the emails of the International Panel on Climate Change or IPCC and broadcasted them to the world. Oh My! What a revelation they were!! These pseudo scientists had bragged to one another in their emails about "fudging the numbers" so that their scary "global warming" plan would work and they could get people to go along with it.

Ladies and Gentleman...NEEVR EVER let someone from any form of government use the Hegelian Principle on you. Hegel said that governments will:
1. The Tale,
Stir up the populace with a FEAR (Future Events Appearing Real) problem,
The Hook
2. Wait for the reaction, and when the populace was frightened enough, which is,
The Sting
3. Come up with the solution, which this time is to get you to pay a "carbon tax" that will be used to offset your "carbon footprint." Which actually means you will hand the international bankers (their handlers) your wallet to pay for a non-existent problem, which is "Climate Change."
 It's kinda like watching the movie "The Sting" isn't it? Except this time, YOU get the shaft and not Robert Shaw!!

text: DON'T BE FOOLED BY CLIMATE CHANGE PROPAGANDA. Let me help everyone understand Climate Change from a scientific point of view. The earth tilt and differential from sun to earth rotation create normal cycles. The idea that Global Warming is a natural cycle is well understood from paleo data covering the past 1 million years. For the past million years the natural climate has oscillated between warm periods and ice ages. This shifting in and out of warm periods and ice ages is correlated strongly with Milankovitch cycles. Human impact on climate change is equivalent to a fly on a horses back.
author: Kewina Kamapapeli

text:
The Green deal as it stands is imperfect and can use a few improvements.
The worst part of it would be forcing the early retirement of existing cars to speed up EV adoption as it would likely cause much more emissions than if the transition happened normally as it takes about 12 years for the reduction of emissions of a new vehicle to amortize the pollution of it's manufacturing.
Another issue not everyone can afford a new car and forcing them buy a car they can;t afford or do without would be unfair and cause push back that could delay or even doom the plan.
We need to also back more technologies than just lithium ion battery electric cars as depending on just one technology is what got us in this mess in the first place. 
I suggest also investing as much in biofuels such as switch grass and bio butanol from algae which is a drop in replacement for gasoline as this could make existing cars greener and making EV conversions of existing vehicles eligible for a tax breaks.
As well as explore powering vehicles with hydrogen including ICE ones.
¬†Last we need to invest in nuclear power specifically generation IV reactors such as LFTR as it can do in 20 years what would take solar and wind 100 years to accomplish.
Nuclear power already is the second cheapest source of energy at 5 cents per KWh right behind hydro electric power at 4.3 cents per KWh.
¬†Countries that ignore the nuclear option do so at their own peril as they will find themselves at a severe competitive advantage with those who embrace it.
¬†Air travel can be made greener if short haul planes were made hybrid electric where the gas generator section of the turbine is decoupled from the fan.
Long haul lights maybe look into Reaction Engines Sabre engine and the LAPCAT concept.

text:
Cutting out meat and dairy will make the biggest difference to climate change.  It's factual (apart from not having more children).  Anti- trumpets should like facts right? So we have all established we like facts.  Cutting meat and dairy is something all of us can actually do without the government doing anything, but most people are not willing to actually change or inconvenience themselves at all to save the planet.  I'm not saying that Donald Trump isn't a steaming pile of human mucus, but we can actually stop climate change without him, or anyone.  https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/meat-dairy-industry-greenhouse-gas-emissions-fossil-fuels-oil-pollution-iatp-grain-a8451871.html

People admit that climate change is the biggest threat facing humanity (apart from Republicans).  Apart from their big shares in oil and coal industries; do you know another industry that the government has bailed out multiple times? The meat industry.  It's very easy to connect the dots. It makes me sad how many people recognise the threat, but aren't willing to make a single change to their own lives to save the planet.  As Seth said; we have 12 years.  Are you willing to make a change that although it may be hard at first (as all changes are), will actually save the planet? At this point I am actually begging people to do this to save the planet that I also live on. If you don't believe anything I've said, a couple of hours of research will prove everything. A few small changes here and there are NOT going to save us.  It has to be big changes, from all of us.

text:
Moderation is really more the key. 

We need some animal fats and protein for optimal health. Vegans need supplements. Many fruits and vegetables require a lot of water and fuel to grow, and transportation to get to market; they aren't carbon-free. There's a lot of waste in that too. A lot of land isn't suitable for crops and is better used for grazing. Grazing can also be used in a crop rotation. Heck, chickens can be used to reduce insect infestations in orchards. 

Finding a balance is better than eliminating any particular thing.
author: Maryanne Slater

text:
Ok so firstly, there is only one supplement that vegans take and it isn‚Äôt made by animals or plants and that is B12. A Vegan diet is appropriate for all stages of life and has a reduced risk of certain diseases like heart disease, Type II diabetes, certain cancers and hypertension. 
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/27886704/

Secondly, the most comprehensive study done to date which investigated the environmental impact of 40,000 farms found that animal agriculture has the most impact out of any industry on climate change. The link to an article about the study is below: 
http://www.ox.ac.uk/news/2018-06-01-new-estimates-environmental-cost-food

Please take a look at the science. It will set you free. The only reason we still get told to eat animal products is because the governments, the pharmaceutical industry and the animal agriculture industry are all making a hell of a lot of money keeping us sick and uninformed.

text:
greg20067 it‚Äôs not simply the fact that the climate is changing...it is the rate and magnitude of change, both of which are anthropogenic. 

It is possible to alter our technology without abandoning it, even reduce greenhouse gas by afforestation. We can keep internal combustion motor vehicles in the interim by retrofitting to burn hydrogen, which can be cracked electrolytically using photovoltaic arrays.  If industries act smartly, they can profit by diversifying.  Less coal will be needed for power (but still necessary for metallurgy and forging, or if we can find some clever chemists, heavy metal extraction). Petroleum is still necessary for making resilient plastics. Some industries may take a hit in the short run but they can survive it if they plan for the long run and not just executive bonuses.

text:
The look on Chris Wallace's face is precious while Trump explains his "raking the forest" theory wasn't total BS...

There ARE actually proposals for building a "wall" in space - a large grate or swarm of objects to block out sunlight. A space sunshade. It would stabilize the temperature of the planet, particularly in the Equatorial regions, preventing desertification.
There are some kinks to work out - how to build it an keep it perpendicular to the incoming sunlight... And it's possible that it could change animal behaviour in unexpected ways if the Equator got relatively mild.

But it would potentially make it possible to end or reverse desertification in the Sahara.

text:
Funny how the far left can't see how they've turned climate change into a religion. 

You can't even ask things like "hey wasn't the climate way different before the ice age happened? There wasn't exactly a worldwide community of humans back then throwing up CO2 into the air, so why'd it change then?" Even doing that gets you labeled as a climate denier. 

Making someone contemplate that the earth is a rock flying through infinity, and that it is barley allowing life to live on it due to some lucky chemistry and physics (keep in mind there's a reason we have trouble finding other life in the universe), well that turns out to be too complicated. It's much easier to just say someone is a climate denier. They're either paid off or too dumb to understand. 

Oh the irony of that type of thinking as Al Gore and Solyndra runs off with money for doing nothing....   

It's almost the same as religion back when they thought the earth was the center of the galaxy. People who pushed against that thought were labeled as heretics. Socrates was killed for just introducing new ideas into his society. 

The far left tries to push that it is the party of science while it mocks the history of science. Science does not exist in safe spaces. You need to have constant questioning and you need to assume you are wrong in the world of science. The far left that Seth Meyers pushes is the opposite of that. They always assume they're undoubtedly correct and that others are morally (not just factually) wrong. 

BTW

If you're afraid of climate change then you're kind of missing the big picture. Eventually the Earth is going to be swallowed up by the sun (ignore the fact that life will burn up far before that though). No amount of clean emissions is going to save you from that one. 

If you think the earth is going to became like Venus, then how about you pool together a large sum of cash (Bernie can get millions overnight apparently) and then gather the A Team of global scientists, engineers, chemists, physicists, blah blah instead of forcing the false idea that the government is going to fix things? There are plenty of people like Bill Gates or Warren Buffett that would help fund the Manhattan Project version of cleaning up the atmosphere. Isn't it better to keep the power with the people over the government?

text:
I read an article on the GND which said that most current approaches to climate change treat it as an economic phenomenon which can be solved with stuff like taxing carbon. The GND treats climate change as an ongoing crisis, and has the perspective that trying to stop climate change with a carbon tax is like - and I quote the article directly here - "trying to stop Hitler with a fascism tax."
As someone who's spent his entire life in a world going through several different environmental crises at once mostly caused by human activity (though human activity is not inherently bad for the environment), I agree with that.
The Green New Deal is about addressing the problems behind or connected to climate change. It's a starting point for a debate on how to actually solve this problem, but it is going to require going after the powerful corporations responsible for most of the environmental damage we're doing as well as making changes in our daily lives

text:
Just to clarify Indiana Jones (despite being a fictional character) was an archaeologist, not an environmentalist. As such his main concern was recovering or uncovering lost or stolen artifacts, as well as beating seven bells of snot out of Nazis who feebly attempt to dabble in the occult. Which happens to be one of his other hobbies, or rather preferably a secondary occupation. 

To summarise, I think that climate change might not be within the field of expertise for archaeologists per se. But then again, compared to Donald Trump and his cronies, they would actually have a much clearer understanding of the situation by far. I apologise to archaeologists everywhere for potentially offending you all, both student and teacher alike for making such a heinous and debasing comparison, you are incredibly gifted and intelligent people.

"Global warming: the increase in Earth‚Äôs average surface temperature due to rising levels of greenhouse gases.

Climate change: a long-term change in the Earth‚Äôs climate, or of a region on Earth.

Within scientific journals, this is still how the two terms are used. Global warming refers to surface temperature increases, while climate change includes global warming and everything else that increasing greenhouse gas amounts will affect."

text: DON'T BE FOOLED BY CLIMATE CHANGE PROPAGANDA. Let me help everyone understand Climate Change from a scientific point of view. The earth tilt and differential from sun to earth rotation create normal cycles. The idea that Global Warming is a natural cycle is well understood from paleo data covering the past 1 million years. For the past million years the natural climate has oscillated between warm periods and ice ages. This shifting in and out of warm periods and ice ages is correlated strongly with Milankovitch cycles. Human impact on climate change is equivalent to a fly on a horses back.

(The article has another search of Google Books which shows basically the same data, you'd have to scroll through the article to see it though because my phone won't let me link to it.)

So tl;dr,  They've always used both words. In fact, the Google Scholar search shows "climate change" (the CC line) was found in earlier articles than "global warming", which concretely disproves the idea that "they", whoever they may be, changed anything.

text: ¬†@Easter worshipper¬† In the scientific community these terms have been used since the '70s, but in American politics conservative strategist Frank Lutz is successfully credited with shifting the vocabulary from "global warming" to "climate change." This was for the purpose of making rising global temperatures sound less threatening.  Reading up on this guy will help give you insight on political rhetoric that is still used today in terms of semantics and vocabulary.

text:
¬†@Brain Slugs¬† In fact, we are governed by many rules that limit our freedoms.  I agree with you that we must defend our freedom.  On the other hand, from the moment we accept that an economic regime governs our moral values.  Is not our freedom of action also limited?  If we close our eyes every time our system is uneven, we never fix the shot.  We must adapt our system to the reality of today, not the one of 1776.  The wealth of the Nations of Adam Smith is good, but we must not forget that at the time there was a triangular market.  England, Africa, Antilles, goods were routed from England to Africa.  In Exchange we bought raw materials and slaves.  These slaves were sold in the West Indies for raw materials, the invisible hand which had to breathe in sound management, never manifested itself.  It is not for nothing that there have been people like Karl Marx.  Karl Marx reacted in the face of the social life of his time.  Children who worked in the mines, or elsewhere.  That being said, I don't think his vision was perfect either.  But there is probably something in the middle that could better adapt to mankind.  We must apply the same logic that Jesus told the men of his time.  God did not make man for the Sabbath but the Sabbath for man.  Our system must be done according to humanity and not humanity according to the system.
  Certainly we will not find a perfect solution, but at least we must try.  We can try and deceive ourselves as a society, but what does not seem logical to me is to accept the flaws without attempting to correct them.

text:
As it stands, of all the land on Earth, 27% is taken up by animal agriculture. That is more than all forests (26%) and much more than urban areas (1%).

When we include crops, a third of all land on Earth is taken up by farming.

In the USA, your situation is easy to understand. Look at USDA data on food production, look at land use data, etc. It is a bad situation.

Now, look at the oceans. In the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, 46% is fishing nets, and most of the rest is discarded fishing gear. Domestic plastic waste is NOT the main contributor. It is a problem, but the fishing industry is a bigger problem.

Nationally and internationally, the major solution to deforestation, species extinctions, climate change, plastic pollution, and other issues is to turn farmland back into forests and to stop throwing harmful things such as plastic into our oceans. We need to eat less meat and fish. So, no, outlawing cows isn't the answer, but halting their ever-growing population is.

text: I'm not an expert though I play one on the internet, but I think your info on the gyres is out of date. Most of the plastic (by extent certainly, as volume is unknown) is fragments of degrades plastic of unidentifiable origin (iirc 1cm sq and smaller, down to microplastics). The big stuff is fishing gear and stuff off boats, yes, but probably because (a) it takes years for land-originating plastics to make it into the gyres, which means they arrive degraded and (b) fishing gear is made not to degrade in sea & sun. So it's a sampling error essentially. (Additionally, estimates I've read suggest the vast majority of the plastic lost to the sea is not in the gyres at all but is believed to have sunk and/or become polluting microplastics deeper in the water.) The thrust of what you say, well, I broadly agree.

author: Clark Barrett

text:
Here's a global map of the world's current & future usable agricultural land. Green has the ability to grow forests or crops, pink is semi-arid & only has the ability to grow grass or livestock, white is desert, tundra or mountains with minimal agricultural potential http://global-growing.org/en/content/ten-facts-about-agriculture-sub-saharan-africa 

"turn farmland back into forests" Any farmland currently in pink areas cannot be turned into forests. It can be turned into grasslands if you want to & that's a rather smart thing to do to fight climate change, given that grasses in those regions are generally C4 plants & c4 plants make up just 5% of terrestrial bio-mass but account for 23% of terrestrial carbon sequestration. All trees are C3, none are C4 & with C4 species evolving last time the planet warmed in direct response to that as trees died, the logical thing to focus on is the restoration of grasslands not forests anyway. In the US, grasslands are the most endangered eco-system, with less than 0.5% of the original grasslands surviving today! They are the original "Buffalo planes" & support diverse wildlife & plant species, many of which are now endangered due to habitat loss.

The main reason for grasslands destruction is disruptions of natural cycles, with grasses not being allowed to reach maturity & then have their keystone species fertilise, prune & spread their seeds. On grasslands, the keystone species is large grazers, they do the job bacteria do in wet forests, breaking down decaying matter. Without them, the land desertifies. Since the advent of effective guns, we have removed the vast majority of the large grazers from the planet! Total ruminant numbers, including all domestic cows, sheep, goats etc alongside the bison, wildebeest, deer, moose, antelope etc are now at record lows! We have never had so few large grazers on the planet in human history! If we want to save the planet, we need to start with the world's 5 billion hectares of grasslands & get them functioning again, either with wild grazers or livestock managed to behave like wild grazers, moving daily & letting natural grasses reach maturity & seed before allowing them to graze again. 

Saving the forests is great, but climate change is going to kill them anyway! If we want to save the world, we need to focus on the C4 plants & getting carbon back into the soil where it belongs! Half the world's grasslands functioning properly again (only large area currently doing so is the Serengeti) for 10 years would see atmospheric CO2 back to pre-industrial levels! This is cheap & doable now, we all should be pushing for it! Close down ALL feedlots & put all available cows back on grasslands under proper, regenerative agriculture, holistic grazing management! Then approve the Buffalo commons proposal & increase native grazers & their predators as well. Reject all cattle from Brazil & instead insist it come from pink areas of the world on that map, because those are the underpopulated grazer grassland regions!
author: Lilac Lizard

text:
The real problem, of which climate change is only the most immediate threatening consequence, is that 8 billion people are to much to provide everyone with the kind of lifestyle we enjoy, sustainably. period. None of this would be so much of a problem with a world population of 1,5 billion. And solving this issue is just so much harder for 8 billion than it is for 1.5. Compared to what we enjoy, the kind of standard most decision-makers are using as a comparison, the kind of lifestyle we think everyone should be entitled to, the real average standard of living across all the 8 billion people on earth, is pretty miserable. Periods of serious malnutrition, high mortality, unsure future, these things are real for almost everyone except us few. 
So agricultural landuse is a problem? Now why are we doing it? Because a hell of a lot of people eat crops. Fishing gear and over-fishing are problems? Now why are we doing it? Because a hell of a lot of  people eat fish, or feed it to their lifestock. Yes, we need to eat less meat. Absolutely. Not because it is healthy, or natural. It is none of those. It is a necessity, because we are to many, simple as that. The planet can¬¥t take it at that scale. To really make a change within 12 years, we would have to revert to a diet that made people die young in the middle ages. Rye gruel, that is. Not fancy, over-processed soya stuff enriched with some exotic super-grain, that is flown in from some remote highland village in the andes, because that is the stuff that will make us reach 115years. And it is a real problem, because there is no safe and acceptable and agreeable gadget to develop that can just switch it off, no matter what salesmen tell us. But then again, it¬¥s probably already to late, anyway. Would you want to be told you are not allowed to have kids? See?

text:
¬†@Paavo Bergmann¬† You are right, there are a lot of humans. But that doesn't make arguments in favour of cutting down on meat consumption any less valid. Meat is consumed too much in the West, and becoming more popular to the East. It is a health concern for many, and an environmental concern everywhere. Fish is less of a health concern, but as much of an ecological one. If we can survive, without killing off our population or forcing population control measures, by being smarter, why wouldn't we? Growth should be focused on cities ('economy of scale' means that the bigger a city/town, the more efficient per capita for everything from water use to land use) and effort should be made to coax people into more plant-based lifestyles. Among other things.

Humans have always attacked our environment, primarily for food, even before agriculture. We can trace the arrival of the first humans into the Americas by the wake of extinct megafauna they left. Since agriculture, it's only become worse. Estimates of original post-glacial forest cover in the UK, for example, exceed 50%, where now forest cover is around 13%. Most of the land in the UK is covered by pasture (29%), then cropland (27%); and much of the crop is used for fodder. People argue that we can't turn certain land back into forest, but we very much can turn much current farmland into trees. Plant trees. Easy. It takes time for them to grow, but they are the best long-term option.

https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/nov/15/tree-planting-double-uk-climate-change

Rye gruel? Where is this coming from? No, a diet with a large variety of plant foods and fermented things can offer every nutrient we need. We need to diversify crops, not limit them. Monocultures for human and livestock consumption are doing much damage.

100% plant-based diets wouldn't be feasible for many people, mostly in so-called "developing" nations, but for most relatively wealthy people across the globe the plant-based options are numerous and affordable. Nuts, legumes, root veg, greens, fruit, fermented foods, tea, and so on.

Something vegans seem completely unable to grasp - cows don't compete with crops for space!

The government here is funding conversions for chunks  of farmland of up to 1 million hectares at a time & completely restoring entire areas of that size each time it does, so don't give me vegan propaganda that it doesn't work, because there are lists & lists of peer reviewed published studies proving it does!

"You're saying, the forests are all going to die anyway so what's the point?" I'm saying stop the carbon neutral forests from dying & taking countless species with them by focusing on c4 plants & reversing desertification & within 10 years we can stop forests from dying from climate change by reversing it back to pre-industrial levels! Why don't you go read wiki's page on C4 plants, NOTHING to do with Savory there! 

Here you go, heavily edited copy & paste of wiki simplifying it down significantly to make it readable to everyday people
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C4_carbon_fixation
C4 overcomes the tendency of the enzyme RuBisCO to wastefully fix oxygen rather than carbon dioxide in the process of photorespiration.....
C4 plants use PEP carboxylase to capture more CO2....
Using this extra energy, C4 plants are able to more efficiently fix carbon in drought, high temperatures, and limitations of nitrogen or CO2. Since the more common C3 pathway does not require this extra energy, it is more efficient in the other conditions.
In C3 plants, the first step ... of photosynthesis involves the fixation of CO2 by the enzyme RuBisCO ... However, due to the ... activity of RuBisCo, some part of the substrate is oxidized rather than carboxylated, resulting in loss ... and consumption of energy, in what is known as photorespiration.
In order to bypass the photorespiration pathway, C4 plants have developed a mechanism to efficiently deliver CO2 to the RuBisCO enzyme. ...Instead of direct fixation to RuBisCO ... CO2 is incorporated into a four-carbon organic acid, which has the ability to ..(extra processes here).. use this CO2 to generate carbohydrates by the conventional C3 pathway...
The primary function of kranz anatomy is to provide a site in which CO2 can be concentrated around RuBisCO, thereby avoiding photorespiration. In order to maintain a significantly higher CO2 concentration....

C4 plants have a competitive advantage over plants possessing the more common C3 carbon fixation pathway under conditions of drought, high temperatures, and nitrogen or CO2 limitation. When grown in the same environment, at 30 ¬∞C, C3 grasses lose approximately 833 molecules of water per CO2 molecule that is fixed, whereas C4 grasses lose only 277. This increased water use efficiency of C4 grasses means that soil moisture is conserved, allowing them to grow for longer in arid environments.

Today, C4 plants represent about 5% of Earth's plant biomass and 3% of its known plant species.[10][16] Despite this scarcity, they account for about 23% of terrestrial carbon fixation.[13][17] Increasing the proportion of C4 plants on earth could assist biosequestration of CO2 and represent an important climate change avoidance strategy. Present-day C4 plants are concentrated in the tropics and subtropics (below latitudes of 45 degrees) where the high air temperature contributes to higher possible levels of oxygenase activity by RuBisCO, which increases rates of photorespiration in C3 plants

text:
‚Äã¬†@A Man, Alive¬† To be clear on wild grazer numbers, the Serengeti is 1.5 million hectares & has roughly 2 million large (cow sized) ruminants grazing it. It also has an additional half a million other animals like zebra, lions etc
There are 5 billion hectares of seasonal grasslands like the Serengeti in the world (the pink on that map I linked to), for all to be fully funcitonal would therefore require 10 billion large (cow sized) grazers or 5 billion bison sized grazers (they're double the size of cows) or 8 times the number for sheep sized grazers like antelope & deer (80 billion animals total). That's just for grasslands & excludes all forests. That is the numbers that were present before humans started shooting them!
Currently there are 1.5 billion cows on the planet & around 1.1 billion sheep & goats. Pigs & chickens aren't ruminants or large grazers, so we'll exclude them, so if 96% of the world's ruminants are only those 2.6 billion cows, sheep & goats & the sheep & goats are only a 1 to 8 ratio on size, that means we have less than 1.8 billion cow sized ruminants total on the planet instead of the previous 10 billion, even including the 4% of wild animals remaining. Rounding up to 2 billion, that means that methane emissions from ruminants like cows, wilderbeest, bison etc are now 1/5th the emissions from pre-industrial revolution, so I'm assuming you have graphs showing methane emissions have decreased to only 1/5th of their former levels in the last 200 years right? If not, then clearly ruminants aren't impacting methane levels are they - or actually they are, the shortage of ruminants means burning is needed to replace them & the latest NASA study actually shows that burning grasslands is the missing link to explain methane levels. That's what happens when you removed grazers! It causes far more damage! And none of what I've just said has anything to do with what Savory is saying does it!
author: Lilac Lizard

text:
Our World in Data is supported by a grant from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

sorry fella.  Im one of those conspiratards that believes in social engineering NWO agendas.  and this Gates fella is one of em.
