author: Gizziiusa

text:
¬†@A Man, Alive¬† I never said i trade one against the other. Much good can be done if your advice is followed, I am sure, and I agree with almost everything. Except that a fully healthy, vegetarian diet is also ressource and energy intensive, and a very modern thing, requiring food preocessing and long distance transport among others.
And as you said: For most wealthy people affordable. So, about 8%. Maybe 700Mio ppl out of 8 billion. Who all want the standard of living we enjoy. Considered that? Your whole concept is based on the idea of keeping the distinction between the wealthy few and the rest. 
Alas, my opinion, and here we differ, is: It will not be enough. Saving a the planet (aka, "our environment/habitat") without reducing both population and living standard is an illusion. Whether it is myth or ideology, i am not sure yet.
author: Paavo Bergmann

text:
¬†@Gizziiusa¬† in this case it doesn't really matter what that data shows/if it's real, cause she doesn't know how to read it anyway. Easy sample https://www.google.com.au/search?q=australian+cattle+station&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjA3tPOkMfaAhXDGpQKHVZgBRAQ_AUICigB#imgrc=mGGS9nGHV4stmM: 70% of Australia is used for animal agriculture, I don't think anyone's questioning approximates on that, but sphericaldice can't grasp that if cattle weren't on it, that land would be added to her "barren land" & same everywhere, so her entire argument is mute because she can say "27% of land is livestock & 19% is barren land" or she can say "46% of land is barren land" and either way her vegan logic is still completely useless in terms of available land for crops or forests, cause the livestock are only on the land she's not even interested in listing because she considers it as useless land. She just needs to choose if she wants to let people actually feed the world with cows or if she wants to destroy the world with fire & desertification

If you want info a source on conservation that I think you'll trust, try this one www.rightwaytobegreen.com/2017/07/06/fake-green-fake-science-the-sierra-club-doesnt-add-up/ same thiking as you have, but with clear evidence of what we could be doing to fix the world - if there wasn't too much money involved in intentionally keeping it messed up! Did you know that the carbon credits etc industry is financially bigger than the fossil fuel industry? Info on that link :)
author: Lilac Lizard

text:
¬†@Lilac Lizard¬† 
The reason the cows are at 27% is that they are currently on that shrubland & barren land as you put it
sphericaldice can't grasp that if cattle weren't on it, that land would be added to her "barren land" & same everywhere

Barren land includes deserts, salt flats, beaches, exposed rock, quarries, etc. On the whole, no, cattle are not grazed on these places, and where they are, the land can't support many of them.

Australia is an example on one end of the spectrum. Most of it is barren, desert, where livestock are grazed. And even there, deforestation is a major problem.
https://www.wilderness.org.au/news-events/10-facts-about-deforestation-in-australia
http://www.convictcreations.com/animals/climatechange.html
and, because it's a neighbour, NZ:
https://www.landcareresearch.co.nz/science/plants-animals-fungi/ecosystems/prehistoric-settlement/deforestation


Cows on prime cropland outperform all crops in terms of calories per hectare except for rice & sugarcane

Source for that?

We can talk calories, protein, pretty much any micronutrient; or energy, water, or land required to produce a certain weight of food; and your cows will always lose.
https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1748-9326/11/10/105002
http://www.environmentreports.com/change-your-diet-change-our-destiny/
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edible_protein_per_unit_area_of_land


incredible results being achieved with it, completely eliminating all run off & pollution problems
lists & lists of peer reviewed published studies proving it does
Lists and lists, eh?

You provide multiple sources, which is nice. But most of them are not peer-reviewed studies.

The last one says,
"a pathway to sustainable intensification by providing green forage at levels equal or even higher than those achieved under continuous traditional grazing"

See that word, intensification? That means they're looking for a way of intensifying cattle grazing while increasing green biomass. You know what works better than managing grassland with massive herds of cattle? Not having the fucking cattle.

Things the above links all have in common are the assumptions that:

(1) we want to find ways to make cattle production more sustainable, rather than just stop rearing cattle
(2) grassland was always grassland and should always be grassland (much of it wasn't, and needn't be)


C4 plants are able to more efficiently fix carbon in drought, high temperatures, and limitations of nitrogen or CO2

Great. And?

https://biologydictionary.net/c3-c4-cam-plants/
"C4 plants include corn, sugar cane, millet, sorghum, pineapple, daisies and cabbage."

What exactly do we need cattle for here?
author: A Man, Alive

text:
¬†@A Man, Alive¬† "You provide multiple sources, which is nice. But most of them are not peer-reviewed studies." says the person who just suggested cabbage, pineapples & daisies are C4 plants lol
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brassicaceae#Phytochemistry 
& I gave plenty of links to peer reviewed stuff, FAR more than you have! The only one of your links that has any potential for credibility is https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1748-9326/11/10/105002 but it's outdated & debunked by https://www.researchgate.net/publication/312201313_Livestock_On_our_plates_or_eating_at_our_table_A_new_analysis_of_the_feedfood_debate I suggest you read it & update your reference links to reflect accurate information on what livestock actually eat. The rest of your links I'm not bothering with. Please provide google scholar sourced links.

"What exactly do we need cattle for here?" actual C4 plants have very high fertiliser requirements, the only efficient way to achieve this for 5 billion hectares of grasslands is with cattle

"Great. And?" therefore, as that is the weather we are increasingly dealing with, they are therefore the plants we need to be focusing on growing. We can also use them to produce food & therefore leave forests alone to save species there. By food production, I mean that at least a large part of that MUST be perennial C4's to reduce current unsustainable erosion rates from croplands

"(2) grassland was always grassland and should always be grassland (much of it wasn't, and needn't be)" I'm talking about Koppen climate classification land semi-arid or arid, so yes it must be grassland or wasteland. Koppen climate classification semi-arid cannot grow forests! It's that simple! & most of that land has been grassland for 300 million years. Homosapians have been around for not even 1 million years, so rather arrogant of you to think you should be changing 300 million year old eco-systems don't you think?

"See that word, intensification? That means they're looking for a way of intensifying cattle grazing while increasing green biomass. " yes, they were able to add even more cows than under traditional systems, while still increasing the amount of grass growing on the land! This is common that farmers put 4 times more cattle on the same land & still get better restoration & carbon sequestration than nearby cropland or empty land is getting!

"Cows on prime cropland outperform all crops in terms of calories per hectare except for rice & sugarcane Source for that?" simple calculations based on quantities of food cattle eat compared with quantities grown per hectare of land per month/year
For every 100 kg liveweight, cattle will eat an average of 2.7‚Äì3 kg of dry matter daily (born at 30kgs, reach 450-500kgs by 12 months of age (slaughter)
On prime land, hay will produce 2 tonnes of hay per hectare, 8 harvest per year (16 tonnes), so you do the calculations :) Alternatively use corn, but add all the stalks into that dry matter the cows are eating instead of just the cobs we can eat & also remove maturing & drying time, since that's not needed when the cattle are eating the whole plants, so 2 months instead of 4 for maturity, plus no issues with cobs only forming in response to reducing day length, so 6 crops per year instead of 1-2

& I didn't even add into my numbers, but if you want to make it even more impressive, each 1200 pound cow will produce 4 tonnes of manure per year, which can be farmed to produce around 2 tonnes of maggots per year to feed chickens (just be introducing the flies into the area & then leaving the paddock empty for 3 days after the cows are moved on, as well as & allowing some patties of maggots longer, to mature to flies). Layer chickens require 45kgs of maggots per year (1/4 pound per day) & in return produce 25,000 calories worth of eggs per year per chicken, so there's about another 15 million calories being produced from that too, which even without the cows outperforms most crops vegans eat, but the cows are producing over 30 million calories per hectare you will see if you do the calculations based on crop yield next to food needs & growth time

"and, because it's a neighbour, NZ:" Antarctica's closer, why didn't you use that as the comparison? It's just as relevant as NZ is! Anyway, those are clearly bias non-scientific studies based on their names, so I'm not even going to bother following, I'll just counter with some basic facts 

http://www.un.org/en/events/desertification_decade/whynow.shtml
Between 1983 and 2003, approximately 16% of the land improved, of which 20% is cropland and 43% rangeland.
                                Cropland Rangeland Forest Globally
Degrading land      20%           20-25%          42% 24%
Recovering land      18%                  43%          23% 16%

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endorheic_basin
"endorheic lakes are usually more sensitive to environmental pollutant inputs than water bodies that have access to oceans, as pollution can be trapped in them and accumulate over time." & some samples of these 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lake_Gregory_(South_Australia) surrounded by cattle stations & listed by "birdlife international" for it's importance for birds
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dulkaninna cattle station 110 years run by same family, again conservation area
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lake_Hope_(South_Australia) pastoral lease since 1860 & again listed as internationally important under the Ramsar Convention of Important Wetlands

http://www.abc.net.au/news/rural/2012-10-18/threatened-species-surviving-in-simpson-desert/6122298 and no impact on foliage levels & wildlife in grazed v non-grazed areas of the desert

"Barren land includes deserts, salt flats, beaches, exposed rock, quarries, etc. On the whole, no, cattle are not grazed on these places, and where they are, the land can't support many of them." Any part of a beach that is underwater at any point in tidal movements is not counted in the planet's land area, so sorry but you are wrong on that & the rest of those that you listed are either tiny in size or are used extensively as much of the world's primary grazing land. Very small parts of the planet are pure rock, most are a mix of rocks & eroded rocks with manure in them & these steep areas are extensively used for livestock due to their lack of suitability for crops due to erosion crops cause on that land, while cattle do not. Quarries you can see in the earlier link I gave if you want to & how cattle are used extensively in mine remediation work & here's a list of countries & their agriculture, so you can look for yourself to see how much desert land in the world is used for livestock. Australia is the norm, it is not an outlier http://www.fao.org/countryprofiles/en/ (then click "FAOSTAT Country Profiles" in "Reports and statistical data" for the countries you want to look at)
author: Lilac Lizard

text:
¬†@Lilac Lizard¬† 

Let's start again. I don't think we were ever quite as divided as we've made it seem. My first comment was primarily a call for the regeneration of forests worldwide, and certainly not a call to ignore grassland.

Your first response linked to a page which you claimed showed desert etc in white.
Green has the ability to grow forests or crops, pink is semi-arid & only has the ability to grow grass or livestock, white is desert, tundra or mountains with minimal agricultural potential

To be clear, this is false. Look again. Green, orange, and white are 'humid', 'arid', and 'outside extent of agriculture' respectively. For example, the South American rainforests are in white. Not desert, just not currently 'within' the extent of agriculture. But this is clearly false, as areas we know to be agricultural in Australia, Scandinavia, the USA, Canada, etc are marked in white. So I don't know what to do with the map.

Anyway, after that, much of your first response does make sense. I do not agree with any of your solutions, but we do agree on a few key points.

In the US, grasslands are the most endangered eco-system, with less than 0.5% of the original grasslands surviving today! They are the original "Buffalo planes" & support diverse wildlife & plant species, many of which are now endangered due to habitat loss.

Sure. Don't forget about original forests there either, though.
https://www.fia.fs.fed.us/library/brochures/docs/2012/ForestFacts_1952-2012_English.pdf
"Since 1630, about 256 million acres of forest land have been converted to other uses‚Äîmainly agricultural."
818 million acres of the 2.3 billion acres of land area in the U.S. is forest and woodland today as compared to around 1 billion in 1630.

But even ignoring forest... why is the answer for grassland to promote domesticated herds? Why not wild?


we need to start with the world's 5 billion hectares of grasslands & get them functioning again, either with wild grazers or livestock managed to behave like wild grazers, moving daily & letting natural grasses reach maturity & seed before allowing them to graze again.

23% of sequestration is done by C4 plants. OK. In hot climates suitable for C4 plants, I agree that where land offers potential for them, let 'em rip.

Yes, we agree. But again what reason to choose livestock over wild grazers? As long as humanity is addicted to animal food, there will be little responsible management of such herds. There is little now, as you yourself are pointing out. The issue of biodiversity is also important. The long list of ruminants you posted is great. Would it be better to continue raising cows in their place?

https://www.iucn.org/commissions/world-commission-protected-areas/our-work/grasslands

Grasslands are, like forests, an important ecological feature, and we agree that they should be protected. Protecting them surely does not involve amassing herds of domestic cattle in them...?

Half the world's grasslands functioning properly again (only large area currently doing so is the Serengeti) for 10 years would see atmospheric CO2 back to pre-industrial levels! This is cheap & doable now, we all should be pushing for it! Close down ALL feedlots & put all available cows back on grasslands under proper, regenerative agriculture, holistic grazing management!

We can agree on closing down feedlots, and surely agree that the further destruction of any forest or grassland for agriculture is something we want to avoid. Why not just stop promoting livestock agriculture altogether? There's a definite feeling I get from arguments like yours: "I believe the climate is changing, I want it to stop, but I want to do it by promoting human management of ecosystems in order to raise meat, rather than looking at what the land used to look like worldwide and promoting a return to it through the retreat of humankind and replenishment of prior ecosystems."


Forest, grassland... the destruction is continuing. Why rave about the wonderful benefits of flooding grassland with cattle while never once appearing to consider, and certainly never admitting, that a reduction in meat consumption even in just the world's wealthier nations would contribute tremendously to slowing climate change?
author: A Man, Alive

text:
¬†@A Man, Alive¬† "Green, orange, and white are 'humid', 'arid', and 'outside extent of agriculture' respectively." yes they have categorised what areas of the world have potential for agricultural use based on climate. That's my whole point. Crops can only grow in "humid" areas, if you want to use land beyond "humid" for agriculture, then the only option is livestock agriculture for that land, since crops are incapable of growing anywhere outside the green zones. The pink areas marked on that map are in fact "semi-arid" not "arid" & as such are highly suitable for animal agriculture, as they are the planet's traditional grazing lands, the lands where large grazers are the keystone species.

"areas we know to be agricultural in Australia, Scandinavia, the USA, Canada, etc are marked in white." yes they are. Those lands are far lower in productivity than the green & pink areas, but yes, people will push the boundaries & try to farm beyond the zones considered as usable. The areas beyond that zone in Australia for example are grazing at a rate of 1 cow per 10 hectares instead of the regular 10 cows per 1 hectare used within the pink area. They also require installation of watering points for the cattle at regular intervals as there are no rivers or other natural drinking water sources in that area, no doubt the reason kangaroos evolved the abilty to hop in order to travel over 100kms per day, along with the ability to drink water only once every 3 days, so that they could graze those lands that are up to 300kms from the nearest water source, with each grass plant spread a few metres apart. Because humans have found a way to use that land agriculturally, doesn't mean it's actually within the accepted range of agricultural land. Same with the cold & altitude in the other areas you mention there .

& btw I said & you quoted "with minimal agricultural potential" I never said it can't be used at all, because I'm quite aware that some of that land is in low level agricultural use

"So I don't know what to do with the map." A map like that I've found very hard to find, I wish there was a clearer one, but that's the best I've found, but it is a very good general base. I mostly actually just wish there was a larger version of it. Anyway, if you want to see the base, but more complex data used to create that map, try here https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification That is what that map is based on, Koppen climate classifications as to what grows in what climates 
"For example, the South American rainforests are in white. Not desert" because again that map I linked to is just showing 3 categories, arable, livestock & unsuitable. It doesn't separate out dry desert, tundra or excessive rain or altitude, it just puts them all into the white category. Crops cannot be grown in areas getting over 60mms of rain every month in the form of daily heavy storms, it simply washes away the seed & also all nutrients as well as failing to provide the required drying off period for crops to store, likewise cattle cannot handle that level of soggyness under their feet to eat perennial grasses planted in those areas, as they suffer fungus, having evolved to live on dry grasslands, therefore, those areas are outside the range of agriculture for all commercial crops & livestock we currently grow in the world. If you look in detail at the koppen classification map you'll be able to see what the problem is with each area you think doesn't belong in the white category, I was just simplifying it with the 3 colour map.

I'm going to separate my responses for easier reading :) next to come soon
author: Lilac Lizard

text:
¬†@A Man, Alive¬† "Sure. Don't forget about original forests there either, though.... 818 million acres ... is forest and woodland today as compared to around 1 billion in 1630." Just editing what you wrote a little further with ... where removed to make the numbers there clearer. 46% was forest when whites arrived, now 34% is forest. I dont' have the numbers on grasslands, but I think we both know that they were substantial, given that they supported 30 million bison (who are double the size of today's large bulls), so when there are now only 0.5% of those grasslands remaining, I'd say that is a MUCH more serious problem than forests that have only seen a 10% reduction don't you? 99.5% reduction & extinction v 10% reduction & extinction, pretty clear cut to me!

"mainly agricultural." yes & lets be very very clear here, the bison planes were already the perfect environment for cattle, there was no cutting down of ANY forests in America for livestock! That entire 10% forest clearing was for crops! If you want that 10% back, which seems to be really important to you, then the ONLY way you can acheive that is via the reduction of CROPS! You cannot achieve that via the reduction of grazing land, as it is different koppen climate classifications & forests simply do not grow on semi-aird lands, likewise, if you try to grow crops on them, the result is a dustbowl, because they are simply not suited to the constant planting & harvesting of pioneer species, short growing, short rooted crops. I mean tbh no land on the planet is suited to that! Anytime anyone plants crops anywhere, it will always cause serious land damage because nature designed pioneer species to act as short term erosion stoppers ONLY, they were never meant to be harvested & replanted repeatedly! There is simply no ecologically friendly way to plant a field of pioneer species on their own & then remove them a few months later leaving the ground bare. Never has been & never will be! This is why we are losing 75 BILLION TONNES of carbon rich top soil through crop production every year! (and that is a hell of a lot of carbon going into the air!)

" why is the answer for grassland to promote domesticated herds? Why not wild?" 
1. We know full well that if the grazers don't keep moving & allowing the grasses to fully regrow between grazings, that we will damage the ground probably just as much as not having them there & we will certainly still cause the plant species extinctions if the plants can't reach maturity & produce seed, therefore whatever animals are used MUST move regularly.

2. cost. Who's going to pay to constantly move wild animals? & are they really wild with that happening anyway? Wild animals will spread out & remain in a small area & act exactly the same way as cows do if there is no threat to them & therefore cause exactly the same damage as badly managed cows. Just look at zoos around the world to see this. 

3. the alternative to human herders or fences for wild animals is predators that keep eating their weak & babies if on their own. For that to work, very large areas of space are needed so that animals can form very large herds to feel safe from predators. After a fortune is spent on securing corridors or huge continuous chunks of land for this, predators now find they cannot easily target young or weak animals in the large herd & so they turn their attentions to easier prey, such as lone human children & most people have an objection to living near this, therefore removing the available land for this system, resulting in a situation such as only 0.5% of a country being set aside for natural use & any animals that venture beyond it's boundaries being shot. 

Not very effective for large scale genuine conservation is it! Compare that to Alan Savory's property in Zimbabwe, where he uses a domestic herd to tend & repair damaged land in a controlled way, while also letting wild animals live side by side with them. Because the domestic herd is doing the main seed spreading & fertilising work, it doesn't matter that the elephants & zebra are wandering around on their own or in small groups & in fact, he uses them to his advantage, by creating as I said above, with a large protected herd, therefore causing the lions that are sharing the land with the goats & cows to not even bother trying to kill the domestic animals, but rather to go for the easier solo wild animals. I don't see a situation like this https://youtu.be/q7pI7IYaJLI?list=PL1mdVN1WPaRkJ7K-1vi2VTLfyL2Z9W7zF&t=652 as negative for the land, when considering that it is funding the presence of all the wild animals now found there. If you don't want domestic animals, you need to fund the alternatives & I'm not seeing you doing that!
author: Lilac Lizard

text:
¬†@A Man, Alive¬† " In hot climates suitable for C4 plants" yes they are only suited to hot climates & hot wet climates we will want for our crops (the c4 rice conversion project is an interesting one for that for the future though) , so yes, they will be limited to that area in genuine usefulness. C4's cannot be used in cooler climates efficiently (although "painted mountain corn" is an interesting little project that really should be getting way more attention from people with a genuine interest in feeding the world, since it's a c4 growing over 5000ft altitude in areas with only 2-3 months frost free!) so overall I'm not suggesting c4's be planted outside their native range in cold areas (unless climate change changes their native range, then we should extend them to the new hot dry areas). Cooler areas c3 plants are better & cool wet areas, trees or permanent plants are better for the environment than pioneer species repeatedly removed & replanted.

"I agree that where land offers potential for them, let 'em rip." remember though that because of that extra step in their photosynthesis, they require extra energy to fuel it, so they are very heavy feeders, evolving alongside large herds of grazers that were smothering them with manure each time they were pruned. They are used to a situation where almost all their growth is recycled into fresh fertiliser for regrowth via grazers eating them, pooping it out & dung beetles burying that seed filled dung under the surface where erosion & sunlight don't wash away or deactivate the nutrients. For c4's to grow well they need extensive quantities of fertiliser, needs to be a whole herd of animals not just one of two (if not using chemicals, corn uses MASSIVE amounts of chemical fertiliser to grow it for humans to eat!)

"But again what reason to choose livestock over wild grazers?" because I'm paying to fund this (as are 95% of the population) & you're not. Again, if you want to fund it, go ahead, but otherwise, you need to accept where the funding for this is coming from & it's coming from meat eating & also from trophy hunters! The left side of politics is contributing next to no funding for any of this & unless you do, it will remain a pipe dream & never eventuate! Look at even basic proposals like the "buffalo commons" & the trouble funding that! https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buffalo_Commons

"As long as humanity is addicted to animal food, there will be little responsible management of such herds." on the contrary, feedlots are a problem, but if consumers demand grass fed, then economics actually causes responsible management, since the moving daily results in 4 times as many animals being fed on the same space, so farmers have financial intensives to manage well. 

Lets put this a different way, The Great Barrier Reef is in trouble! Climate change is hitting it hard, but so is nutrient runoff, feeding crown of thorns starfish that then eat it to death. The Australian government has trialled a number of different strategies in the agricultural runoff area, all voluntary. It funded the conversion of over 1 million hectares of cattle farms to holistic grazing, paying for water points in each paddock & extra fences, but no ongoing funding, that was it! Farmers get that if they agree to train in the system & follow it, but there is no enforcement, they can convert back to regular if they choose to. Not a single cattle farmer has converted back! Not only that, many of those farmers have now used the profits they have made from their quadrupling of meat production to buy additional farms in new areas & self-fund the infrastructure for holistic grazing on those as well. In most cases, they have bought dilapidated land with serious damage to it for super cheap prices, since it can't grow anything & they are restoring that land back to prime quality land, many becoming entrepreneurs, buying poor, selling after repair, buying new & repeating. Each time they do that, they not only improve that land for themselves & their cattle, but also for native animals & plants, all while making lots & lots of money. Nothing wrong with getting money for repairing the planet.

Now right alongside & mixed into these cattle farms is the sugarcane industry, also with huge runoff issues & also put under voluntary programs to reduce fertiliser run off & use it more efficiently. Now again this is more profitable to the farmers right? Less fertiliser costs means more profits? (and the Australian government removed all fertiliser subsidies decades ago in an attempt to reduce use & encourage better land management practices, so fertiliser costs are high) So here's how that one's going http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-10-11/laws-not-stopping-fertilser-runoff-to-reef/10348718 complete fail. Even tightening & still a complete fail! 100% compliance with run off rules from grazers, very low compliance from crop farmers because there's just not the financial intensives with the crops as there is with the cattle management 

And additional to all of that, there are some extreme tactics needed at times with very poor quality land, tactics that can only be achieved with domestic animals, such as the overnighting pens seen in that Savory video above, not to mention issues like a lack of available large herding animals for use in many countries such as Australia. It's easier to herd cats than kangaroos. Bison could certainly be used though if people preferred them in America, but right now, they will need to be eaten to fund the operation - unless you are offering alternative funding options
author: Lilac Lizard

text:
¬†@A Man, Alive¬† "The long list of ruminants you posted is great. Would it be better to continue raising cows in their place? " 
look there are many areas of the world where what I would like to see is the creation of new Serengeti style areas. Map out an area for a new wildlife refuge, with millions of hectares of land involved. Map out an annual migration route for a large herd & then begin doing like Savory is doing on his property, but mega, mega scale!  Bring it up to 50,000 cows & goats instead of just the 500 he has! Pay 100 or so herders to manage that herd & run them through the migration route & in the process improve the land, bring them full circle & continue them into round 2 of the migration route, siphoning off some of the livestock to continue paying the wages of the herders. When local wildlife rescue groups find wild babies that have been orphaned or otherwise need care, give them the basics & then release them into the domestic herd. Grab some from the Serengeti as well & breeding programs in zoos & add them into the herd. by having a herd that large, they will barely have any contact with the humans anyway, will just be in the middle of a moving mass of animals. Year after year repeat the migration route, collecting more & more stray wild animals as they realise that this mega herd is the safest place to be because we now start releasing some predators into the area to reduce the need for the human herders & restore instinct. As the wild animal percentage in the herd increases, gradually reduce the number & level of herding, just some gentle nudging & monitoring to ensure they are learning the migration route & passing it down to their babies. Eventually the last of the domestic get pulled out & the herd allowed to continue doing it's own thing, just with radio trackers on some of them & some basic supervision, which potentially doubles as tourism dollars, or carbon credit dollars.

That would be great to see imo, but you know what, right now there's no funding for land for that. If it happened, the land would improve & then become the target for acquisition for corrupt politicians & it would crash & burn, not to mention we still can't even stop poaching! So yes, I'd like to see wild animals used BUT we have 12 years to reverse climate change! That is not going to happen in 12 years! Livestock CAN & that is why that must be the first avenue we go down imo. There is nothing wrong with using livestock anyway on land currently devoid of wild animals. It's a much more environmentally friendly way of producing food than these repeated pioneer species crops are, especially when combined with the massive numbers of animals we are dehoming & poisoning to protect those crops! Livestock on grasslands has FAR less carnage all round than that has!

"Protecting them surely does not involve amassing herds of domestic cattle in them...?" well right now the only people offering to fund what's needed are meat eaters & hunters! So do you want trophy hunting or herds of cows? & if neither, then unless you have an alternative funding proposal, you are actually condemning the grasslands to their death. Think of it like child labour, you might not like it, but when the choice is that the child works or starves to death because they couldn't afford to buy food, then my vote is to let them work short term while addressing the main problem & also improving their working conditions until that's done. Child labour I would want almost completely ended long term (paper run etc is fine with me), cattle farming I have no problem with as long as it's managed properly, so no doubt we have different views on the long term on that, but isn't the short term goal the same? To fix climate change & to improve the lives of cows etc while figuring out what the next step is?

One more point on that too, which you're not going to like, but it is reality. Your link is for temperate grasslands & they are hugely important, but so are the seasonal grasslands found in warmer climates, they are probably even more important than the temperate ones for climate change reversal, since they're the c4's, while the temperate ones will be a mix of c3 & c4, likely tending towards mostly c3's (long term c3's will potentially need more protection as they will lose their current areas to more tropical species, but they may pick up new tundra land too, time will tell) anyway, back to the bit you won't like, using that Barrier Reef run off zone as the sample area. That region has seen HUGE increases in species diversity https://youtu.be/oPLXsqS9SSc?list=PL1mdVN1WPaRkJ7K-1vi2VTLfyL2Z9W7zF&t=105 but how that is done & particularly how the natives are brought back from apparent oblivion is with the use of cows as tools to repair the ground. In areas that have had years of chemical fertilisers used, soil is dead! There are insufficient microbes in the soil to allow the growth of the native grassland species (1/3rd of all the world's arable lands are damaged to the point that they can barely produce crops anymore due to overuse of chemical fertilisers causing serious damage to soil microbes & without the microbes, the plants can't turn chunks of iron into absorbable iron, can't turn shells & dead animal hoofs into usable calcium & magnesium etc etc) These lands take decades to restore with regular grazing, never restore without grazing, or alternatively, they can be restored in only a matter of months with strategicly used cows as tools. This is what mine restoration does to turn rocks from the middle of the earth into soil & this is what these Barrier Reef farmers have also been doing to access native plant seeds that were dormant for decades due to a loss of microbes. it looks horrible, but remember it's only being used at night here (mines do it day & night) but 2 weeks of this can return most, if not all native plant species to an area https://youtu.be/fnv1tDuzjiM?list=PL1mdVN1WPaRkJ7K-1vi2VTLfyL2Z9W7zF&t=158 Farming has damaged the planet & so now properly managed farming has become the best way to fix it. Fight fire with fire, use the techniques that caused the damage, but altered to become the most powerful weapon to fix it
author: Lilac Lizard

text:
¬†@A Man, Alive¬† "We can agree on closing down feedlots" yes & most of the western world's populations agree on this! This is why techniques like holistic grazing have so much potential, because most people will very happily get on board to make a small change to end the feedlots (ok this works for ruminants, doesn't work for pigs & so the "bacon" still needs some work, lots of resistance there! but I want to focus on what's doable & build the momentum & then it's easier to take the next step & the next & the next after that)

" and surely agree that the further destruction of any forest or grassland for agriculture is something we want to avoid." 
I'm not sure we are both agreeing on this, because the only way we can stop more forests from being destroyed is to repair that 1/3rd of cropland that's been damaged along with finding more efficient sources of food & you don't seem to be on board with that. It would obviously be good to get free birth control out there for any woman in the world that wants it in order to stabilise global populations, but that will take time, so in the meantime we need more food (or less waste) to feed a growing population. I know my food space requirements because I grow 100% of my plant based foods myself, but I don't think you realise the space needs of your foods. 

Vegans like to talk about how they've heard that their food CAN use less land than meat eaters & yes, grown in the most efficient way possible, 1 hectare of rice paddies can feed up to 500 people on starvation level rations, especially when vegan is thrown out the window & fish & ducks are added into the paddy for malaria & pest control & fertilisation, but the reality is that a typical western vegan diet is incredibly demanding on land requirements & more than that, it demands not only the precious arable land, but the best of the arable land! 

The vast majority of the bulk of your food is likely grown on land with enough water to grow rice, but is likely producing enough food to feed maybe 1 person per hectare not 500 due to your choices in low efficiency foods. If you want to stop rainforests from being cut down, you need to think about the space needs of the plants you eat & then add into those considerations how much fertiliser they need as well & how much damage that does to the land long term https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/dec/02/arable-land-soil-food-security-shortage

What's your food growing space profile? What's your chemical fertiliser use profile? (and remember that if you don't have livestock sharing the land your crops grow on, you will need chemical fertiliser) & what's your food waste profile? http://www.fao.org/save-food/resources/keyfindings/infographics/fruit/en/ I'm guessing the bulk of your food is probably in the 45% waste categories, would I be right? Additionally, what's your crop waste profile? What percentage of the plant grown for you & fertilised for you do you actually consume? & what happens to the rest of that crop that you don't eat? How much land to you make look like this https://grist.org/industrial-agriculture/2011-04-13-big-ag-washing-away-midwest-topsoil/

"Why not just stop promoting livestock agriculture altogether? " because all the problems you've linked to & talk about are coming from only crop production & a few from badly managed livestock production, therefore making reductions in the production of animals like ruminants the worst thing you could possibly do if you believe in what you are saying. Pigs sure, but not cows

"There's a definite feeling I get from arguments like yours:" The feeling I get from your arguments is that you've been told lots of stuff about what's damaging the environment & have bought it without question but sadly some of it's not actually accurate. To your credit, you do actually seem to research though & step outside the vegan propaganda world & I really hope you can continue doing so. Even if you don't change from being vegan, there are still a LOT of options out there that I think you're missing that have SO much potential, but climate change has become an industry & such a strong movement now that some of the legitimate solutions are not even being noticed. We could fully reverse climate change within a decade with minimal changes though holistic grazing, but we could also reverse climate change within a decade by better allocation of currently available money into legitimate climate reversing strategies such as bio-char. If all tree planters out there were instead sent out to "rake the forests" & pack that leaf litter into drums with only 1 small hole in them & then put onto a fire to remove everything except the carbon from that drum & that bio-char then thrown back into the forest, they would actually have a MUCH bigger impact on reversing climate change than they are today!

China has stopped taking recycling from the developed world & so paper materials for recycling are currently building up in massive quantities around the world. If we were to build some bio-char plants & charcoal all that paper waste & then load it onto the back of empty trucks as they go to farms to collect produce, then dump it all into the cropland, where it will hold 70 times it's weight in water, as well as retaining fertiliser & so reducing the need for fertiliser applications & irrigation, we could seriously impact carbon levels in the atmosphere, since we would be locking all that paper carbon out of the atmosphere for 1000+ years! All while increasing food production from the same amount of land! Those bio-char burners can even be designed to burn using the wood gasses that escape during the burning process, so there's not even any carbon emissions needed to do it! There ARE options to REVERSE climate change! We can get atmospheric levels back down to pre-industrial levels within 10 years & very easily, but you need to remember that none of the ways we can do that are new! Bio-char was used in terra-preta before whites even arrived in America! Holistic grazing is 300 million years old, so since we've known about climate change for decades now & still not carried out these reversing actions, it's important to ask why not & to ask what is causing the problems & therefore what can we GENUINELY do to get this problem fixed in the limited time we now have left & holding out for a unicorn is just not helpful for anyone other than those wishing to profit from disaster & don't make any mistake about this, people ARE doing this for profit & they ARE profiting from disasters! The sheep need to wake up & fix this problem from a grass roots level! If you don't want to eat meat that comes from regenerative animal agriculture, then add bbq charcoal to your shopping list each week & bury it in your own backyard & then begin burning it in your community, anywhere that trees look like they might be suffering from a lack of water, anywhere that looks like it could have pollution run off issues, take a little garden trowel, make an opening, put the charcoal pellet in & close it back up again. Do a bag every week & have all your friends join you to do the same. Go to grasslands near you, go to forests near you. If everyone does that or the meat for a decade, this problem will be fixed!

"a reduction in meat consumption even in just the world's wealthier nations would contribute tremendously to slowing climate change" ONLY if what it's calories were replaced with was more beneficial & you have suggested no foods that meet that criteria. Switching from factory farmed to grass fed & therefore forcing conversion to efficient grass feeding systems will do FAR more to reverse climate change than trading meat for beans or almonds! Both those options & almost all others, with current agricultural practices would result is FAR HIGHER greenhouse gas emissions than grass fed meat will! You seem to forget that you are still farting out all that methane when you eat the beans instead of the cows. Your methane is only lower than the cow because you only ate a tiny fraction of the bean plant. The rest of that bean plant was either burnt or broken down by microbes & in the process gave off exactly the same amount of methane as it did when it was broken down inside the cow. The difference being that because the cow wasn't involved, the fertiliser used to grow it emitted nitrous oxide, an ozone destroying greenhouse gas 300 times more potent than CO2!

text: DON'T BE FOOLED BY CLIMATE CHANGE PROPAGANDA. Let me help everyone understand Climate Change from a scientific point of view. The earth tilt and differential from sun to earth rotation create normal cycles. The idea that Global Warming is a natural cycle is well understood from paleo data covering the past 1 million years. For the past million years the natural climate has oscillated between warm periods and ice ages. This shifting in and out of warm periods and ice ages is correlated strongly with Milankovitch cycles. Human impact on climate change is equivalent to a fly on a horses back.

text: DON'T BE FOOLED BY CLIMATE CHANGE PROPAGANDA. Let me help everyone understand Climate Change from a scientific point of view. The earth tilt and differential from sun to earth rotation create normal cycles. The idea that Global Warming is a natural cycle is well understood from paleo data covering the past 1 million years. For the past million years the natural climate has oscillated between warm periods and ice ages. This shifting in and out of warm periods and ice ages is correlated strongly with Milankovitch cycles. text: ¬†@Kewina Kamapapeli¬† of course the wobbling oscillations in tilt and orbital elipse inn their various combinations are as predictable as clockwork. According to these models we are supposed to be currently headed into a temperature drop, which is fortunate because the equally predictable greenhouse effects of human induced atmospheric changes might slightly counter the rapidity of warming. What often gets left out is relative time scale. The greenhouse gas buildup is a result of releasing millions of years of carbon deposit in the span of a century or two. As an analogy: it's one thing to know the the avg lifespan of a human but what we have here is a baby aging that much within a small fraction of that time. Certainly can't call that normal. So be honest about the full context otherwise you're not contributing anything but misleading mystification couched in partial truth.

¬†@S Userman¬† You're an idiot but I teach idiots all the time so here you go. Keep it to just your one car to start. At an avg of 15k miles per year the 25 gallon delta between 40 and 15 means 600 gallons of gas difference. 600 gallons create 19.4 to 19.6 lbs of CO2 each for a total of 11760  extra lbs of CO2 in just one year. Per car. That doesnt even address all the other trace gasses and nitrogen oxides that come from the same gallon. 11760 times 100,000,000 is over a trillion lbs of carbon that didn't need to go there. 

That's the simple math, you can handle that right? According to Scientific American April 09. Releasing a "trillion metric tons of carbon into the atmosphere may cause a most likely peak warming of 2 degrees C which many identify as the danger point." But that's back to CO2 alone. Ot doesnt account for the many other greenhouse contributors....or the other stuff coming from tailpipes.

Same article references emissions must be below 1990 levels by 2050...meaning U.S. must cut by 90% and on path to zero emissions. Of course a 1 or 2 degree rise will already be calamitous. Shall I go on?

Also, lest you wonder, there's approx. 1.42 billion cars in operation worldwide. So your example is less than 1/10th of the real problem.

text:
¬†@Jesus¬† Can't blame them. Other countries are rioting and overthrowing their governments; meanwhile, we're turning to comedians for news because our mainstream media cannot be trusted to do the job of delivering news - in a DEMOCRACY! Your sentiment - that the average American has 0 power - speaks to the complacency that plagues this country. Trump sucks, but the one good thing to come out of it is the way it galvanized people to take action, run for office, volunteer, and participate in the government that dictates how our lives run. Other countries are right to call us out - how is it that one of the most affluent countries in the world elected a crooked turd like Trump to the presidency? And before you try to pass the blame to his idiot supporters, remember our traditionally abysmal voter turnout and the people who refused to vote this last election because they "didn't like either candidate."

Get out and vote. Get your friends to vote. Tell them why it's important and explain the issues. Volunteer for a campaign or to help register voters. Stay engaged. The average person has plenty of power to make a difference, but you have to exercise it. You have to do the work. You have to show up.

text:
It's hard to laugh at the opposition to climate change any longer because I understand my fellow man well enough to understand that if someone in power would just say that it's all okay and that nothing needs to change he/she/it will be lauded as a voice of reason.

I don't think we are fully screwed just yet but we are far from fine, and as things go we are going to burn this world to the ground to show that we don't believe in climate change or global warming, or anything like that because if we don't do that the climate scientists are just going to keep raking in that "World is dying" money so that they can buy loads more electric cars?

I don't care though, in about 3 years only the mentally infirmed will be able to deny what is happening, and that's only because stupid people seem to live the longest of all. God help us all if Donald Trump gets elected again.

Hate me for this all you want because there is no god and that's the point... We cannot be helped if that happens. I know it's not America alone who needs to keep moving our understanding of and ability to fight the effects of climate change by at least putting the breaks on the things we do NOT want to put the breaks on but people still follow us when it's convenient and not cutting back on the use of fossil fuels and plastics and air travel is pretty dang convenient.

text: I absolutely despise Trump, but he isn't completely wrong about Forrest management. One of the biggest issues in Forrest management right now is that we have been so vigilant in preventing Forrest fires in past years that the natural cycle that would have small fires occuring regularly that burn off small bushes and leaf litter have been stopped, allowing for fuel buildup to the point that when a fire does eventually happen it becomes much larger than it would otherwise. To prevent this we can allow for controlled fires to burn off this fuel load (this is often considered risky around populated areas) or we can remove this fuel load manually. While he is wrong about most things including climate change, it is also the case that one of the main causes of devastating Forrest fires is mismanagement.

text:
" or we can remove this fuel load manually. " well if you're going to do that, once removed, stick it in a big drum with a small hole to let gas out, but not let any air in & burn it. Result is bio-char ie, all the carbon from that fuel load is now trapped in solid form & ready to be added to cropfields, where it will hold 70 times it's weight in water, as well as retaining fertiliser, therefore massively increasing productivity of the crops & mitigating against future floods & droughts, all while reducing forest fires. Trump could actually do this & not just slow, but reverse climate change with his forest raking policy! Pity he's too stupid to understand when he has a good idea

& yes, reducing fuel load obviously reduces fire frequency & severity, stopping fires from crowning & causing massive damage. It was practiced by Native people in America & Australia for tens of thousands of years & Australia has returned to it as large scale, fire management, burning as much land as possible anytime the weather will allow them to light fires that won't become major bushfires, volunteers & paid staff, weekday & weekends, year round burning anytime they can!
author: Lilac Lizard

text:
I would love it if my city had good public transportation so that I wouldn‚Äôt need to own a car. My car eats up a lot of my paycheck each month with gas and insurance, and when it breaks it‚Äôs expensive to fix. It would be such a weight off my shoulders if I could still be independent, get to my job, get to stores by public transportation. I wouldn‚Äôt have near heart attacks every time I witness an almost accident or actual accident, or nearly get in an accident myself. I‚Äôm a good driver, but there are SO MANY drivers on the road, more and more as our city grows, even the best drivers make mistakes. It would be great to never have to worry about making a terrible mistake while driving and possibly ending someone‚Äôs life. I never understood why my friends were so excited to get their drivers licenses. Yea, you get to go where you want when you want, but don‚Äôt you realize you are sitting in a heavy piece of machinery that can cause destruction? I don‚Äôt know how many people I‚Äôve had to ask to stop texting and driving while I‚Äôm in the car, and they roll their eyes at me. The car isn‚Äôt driving itself. 
I‚Äôm rambling, but my original point was that I‚Äôd love it if my city had more public transportation. The end.

text:
I've already seen videos right here on YouTube, made with that annoying robot voice narrating "Breaking News," about everything from "McCabe is going to be indicted!" to, "Elizabeth Warren Blackface Scandal!"

Just like last time.

A wide-ranging disinformation campaign aimed at Democratic 2020 candidates is already underway on social media, with signs that foreign state actors are driving at least some of the activity.

The main targets appear to be Sen. Kamala Harris, (D-Calif.) Elizabeth Warren, (D-Mass.) Bernie Sanders, (I-Vt.) and even former Rep. Beto O'Rourke, (D-Tx) four of the most prominent announced or prospective candidates for President.

The goal of the coordinated barrage appears to be undermining the nascent candidacies through the dissemination of memes, hashtags, misinformation and distortions of their policy positions.

But, the divisive nature if many of the posts also hints at a broader effort to sow discord and chaos within the Democratic Presidential primary.

So, just like in 2016, there appears again to be a coordinated anonymous attack underway, focused on finding real fissures in the Democratic party and blowing them up into the most extreme chasms possible. So as to maybe sway the election but potentially to sway Democratic voter's enthusiasm for this race, and certainly to turn them against eachother.

But, whereas the 2016 campaign was marked by the creation of thousands of fake social media accounts that would ultimately be fairly easily identified as bots, this time the effort is a little bit more advanced;

Some of the accounts are believed to be highly sophisticated synthetic accounts operated by people attempting to influence conversations, while others are coordinated in some way by actors who have identified real individuals already tweeting out a desired message.

Tens of thousands of other accounts then work in concert to amplify the core group through mentions and retweets to drive what appears, on the surface, to be organic virality. 

This looks just like what we saw in the 2016 campaign, the social media side of the information warfare against the Democrats and helping Trump, by Russians and by the "Four-chan," community.

And, once the primaries are over, and a nominee has emerged, it's only a matter of time before WikiLeaks begins releasing stolen E-mails and other data from their campaign.

Secondly, the fact that liberals THINK there was a "real" tax rate of 90 percent, DOESN"T MEAN IT COULD BE IMPOSED NOW.

author: S Userman

text:
¬†@S Userman¬†  What's your point about "half the story" here? The person you're responding to never got into any details, but you're touching on the details... the end point is still the same: taxes on the wealthy were higher, and it worked then. You're building a strawman argument around just the "90%" number alone, while still agreeing that it existed. There were a ton of exceptions in it that made it dramatically lower, but stating this just means that NEITHER of you are incorrect, because those taxes were still higher in the end. You are certainly aware that is all these people are saying when they say this, so that error is on you.

Anyways, you're going to have to prove that it's "much easier now to transfer money, and headquarters, and offices, to other places with less rate"... because while that is still a concern, it feels very superficial, and probably wrong in general. The USA is a huge market, and regardless of where a company's headquarters are, tapping into that market is going to come with dealing in it's taxes. In addition to this, a lot of production moved out of the USA as the tax rate lowered... 1950 and onward. Was it a trend started by the high tax rates then, or are there a lot more details that contribute to how these things happened? It's business, so certainly the latter. Could a higher income tax on the wealthy work now? ...In conjunction with other tax rates being aligned to make it more effective not to leave: Yes it could. This goes back to your whole point: If it wasn't the superficial "90% rate" that made it work, but all the very complicated details and exceptions inside of it... why wouldn't a similar thing, complicated details included, work now? Is it likely to find that balance? I don't know, and you clearly do not either.

I'm not saying you're wrong, but I am saying the crux of your arguments are clearly falling on guesses and misunderstandings. This makes your act of superior intelligence really fucking weird.

text: By the Oxford dictionary definition of emergency‚Äîa serious, unexpected, and often dangerous situation requiring immediate action‚Äîclimate change does not qualify. Yes, it‚Äôs important and we need to figure out how to mitigate it, although it‚Äôs doubtful we‚Äôll be able to do it in time. It‚Äôs not as if Climate Change is a giant asteroid headed for earth as some type of extinction event. Climate Change is more like a slow burn where things get ever-so-slightly warmer over the coming decades and centuries. Folks will ultimately need to find a way to move away from the equator and say goodbye to an inch of beach every few years. What will happen are new patterns of migration as people move to newly-temperate climates from areas that become too hot to live in. The big problem will be fighting over resources as more people begin to occupy smaller and smaller areas of the globe, but that‚Äôs centuries away. Besides, who is going to be the first to give up all their modern conveniences‚Äîall the things which exacerbate the problem? I certainly won‚Äôt. Game theory says almost no one will, regardless of level of income or where they live.

text: Dr. Seuss warned about climate change aka global warming years and years ago.  Heck 1917 J.R.R. Tolkien began writing what would eventually be published as the Lord of the Rings now know as the Lord of the Rings trilogy in which the evil orcs cut down the forest to build war machines to destroy the Earth.  Sure it was subtle and you probably didn't even realize that Tolkien was an advocate for the trees and conservation when you sat in the dark room with 50 strangers, eating junk food, throwing their paper and plastic trash everywhere and quoting lines like, "a wizard should know better" and "It takes a long time to say anything in old Entish, and we never say anything unless it is worth taking a long time to say" but indeed the evil orcs were cutting down the forest much in the same way the Lorax found greedy people were doing in the book of the same name by Dr. Seuss.  It seems our parents showed us two of the most influential authors of all time and then forgot their message entirely.  We need trees to breath.  If anyone takes a stand on the left or right as they say then they start name calling and labeling them.  I'm an American.  I'm not a Republican or Democrat.  I don't want power for the sake of power but only want a better country and Earth for my children to one day raise their families in.  I don't want to enslave people into making me shoes in a third world country for pennies a day while they live in extreme poverty and then smile and say they are happy to have the work while military forces pocket pay offs to keep them in line.  The things some of these companies do is criminal and they sit in power beside the politicians.  We are blinded by this struggle of two factions to give us a choice so once we become so disenfranchised by one if we choose we can switch to the other when in fact the same people are supporting this system from the curtain and we once again watch a particular television channel and are indoctrinated into believing so much of this crap.  I fell for it with many Americans after 911 and we sent US soldiers into a country for control of oil under the guise of stopping terrorism.  I remember wanting to enlist and going to the National Guard and testing and then my back went out from a car wreck.  My cousin and my step-father's grandson both went to Iraq.  They both came back but they were both different.  My step-father's grandson had been wounded by an rpg and suffered from PTSD.  He committed suicide a few years after returning.  My cousin is still carrying on but he has a PTSD service dog.  War is hell.  Destroying our atmosphere and trees is dumb...just dumb....fossil fuels are harmful if you've ever seen someone huff gas you know this to be true.....no one talks about nuclear detonations but those mushroom clouds can't be good for our ozone.  We are responsible for about half of the detonations many of which were tests not including nuclear power plant disasters like Chernobyl.  As of 1998 we were responsible for 1,032 of 2,053 detonations.  Sorry for seeming to be all over the issues but they are really one issue, what is best for the American people and all of the Earth's people.  God bless us all.

text: Coldern Ice: It is not about our pleasure. Money causes a materialistic society allowing us to demand whatever we want such as simple conveniences like food that temporarily please us. Companies will just keep producing for the demand- you are paying for slaughter and destruction with your dollar. They only want your money they could care less about the global impact or your health. If you are willing to educate yourself, you would be saying the same as Wild Vegan Child and making this change within your own life as well as supporting others to do the same. Did you know our intestines are 10-12 times the length of our bodies, which is the same of herbivores? Carnivores and omnivores have intestines only 3-6 times as long as their bodies to quickly absorb the nutrients of decaying flesh and to expel it faster. We shouldn't even be drinking cow's milk which contains nutrients specifically to grow a baby calf into a ~1 tonne cow. We should not consume animal products as it does more harm than good to our bodies; rotting while traveling through our intestines allowing cholesterol to build up and the leading cause of death in humans is heart disease and stroke... but someone is making money off of illness, too. Just because we can eat steak after someone does the murder and butchering for us to cook and consume it, it does not mean we should be consuming it. You would think humans have the logical capacity to understand that. Be my guest, enjoy your steak while washing it down with "The Best Speech Ever - Gary Yourofsky" conveniently located here on YouTube. (:

text:
¬†@robert leonard¬† I have experience with working in China in the early 1990's and then again in 2001 to 2011. 


You don't know some key facts, so I'll enlighten you.



China went down the same road as America during the 50's and 60's.. No control on pollution until America was forced to do it. After WWII America entered the Golden Age of Consumerism and development.  No one thought it was as bad as it was as well no one wanted to pule back on the reins and take the chance to stalling the economy.  


After Mao died and Deng Xiaoping took control of the government he recognized how Mao and Mao's form of Communism had no future and proceeded to turn China around in the 1980's. This led to China's Golden Age of Consumerism and it was completely out of control far more than America as China was repressed for so many years. As the situation got worse after 2000 government corruption was off the scales and control was difficult at best. 


China even adopted capital punishment for the most extreme cases of corruption in an effort to gain some control.  This took a long time, China is much larger than America. 


I returned to Shanghai China to set a manufacturing facility in 2007 and I immediately saw so many changes with regulations and monitoring of manufactures.  This was in Shanghai, and when I traveled north to Suqian to visit other factories it was virtually the same as it was in the 1990's!  It was explained to me that it will take more time for the ENFORCEMENT of these new regulations to take effect. 


Finally about 10 years later the government was finally able to enforce existing regulations and enact new laws to curb not only pollution but corruption.  


Its easy for people who have no real knowledge of first hand experience of China to point a finger and criticize.  Once you DO get what the situation really is it becomes clear that its not as it seemed.


Further to the American example of rules and regulations can take good deal of time before they're enforced.  The slaves were freed after the Civil war however were the now former slaved able to enjoy their new "freedom" and "equality'?  NO, they did not, while the federal government had its laws the states and local municipalities had their own, and the federal government could do very little about it...very much like China. 



As a kid growing up in the 50's and 60's I saw "Colored Only" and "Whites Only" signs and this was in NY, not the south.



So no, I'm not smoking any "tea", rather I have first hand knowledge and experience from working overseas for 33 years.

text: Proper grazing practices that replicate natural herd behaviors actually green the land, raise the water table , bring back trees and capture carbon. In parallel, plant crops need to shift to more diversity, perennials and permaculture practices w less tilling and better soil building. But these are not yet standard practices. If they were, it's far more realistic than changing ancient dietary culture. "Animals v. plants" is uninformed, simplistic, unsophisticated and unrealistic.
author: David Gough

text: Not a climate denier, but removing all meat and dairy is a vast oversimplification, and not supported by studies - that you don't quote. Up to 60% of land used to raise animals is not suitable for agriculture, as the huge number of nomadic tribes in desert areas and even cattle ranching in arid areas indicate. On top of that, much agriculture destroys valuable habitat - soy beans in Brazilian rainforest, Palm Oil in Indonesia, african jungles destroyed for Pyrethrum,.
author: Ray Watson

text: ¬†@Ray Watson¬† well put! Too bad it takes more context to explain what you and I understand than the "meat bad" school. I'm afraid that an increasing disengagement with nature is leading to the dismissal of viable solutions. I liken it to a how a  culture that doesn't fish will lose interest in what's going on in the water, and the fish lose. Or how the diseases spreading in our deer result from a declining interest in hunting. Instead we have this game of moral "one-upsmanship" that dismisses the real work of tuning our policies and cultural practices to ecological realities.

text: Try sitting through one of his live stream-of-conscious rambles, such as the ones he delivers before getting a thorough ball licking from his "cabinet" of odious sycophants. Almost nothing he says makes any sense at all. Presumably, the shtick chatting to reporters from behind his desk in the cabinet room is intended to make Trump appear commandeering and powerful (one of his "best words" ‚Äì he's obsessed with it), but these pre-meeting sessions just make him seem borderline mentally incompetent. Nothing he says makes any sense at all; for the most part, it's just a lot of incoherent notions and infeasible ideas that are barely even strung together and usually end up going nowhere. What he often seems to do is dream up some odd, hypothetical situation and then devise a ridiculous proposal to address the imaginary non-problem he's just complained about (e.g., everybody in the world has been "laughing" at the U.S. and treating it "unfairly" because up to now American negotiators have been "suckers" according to Trump) before then mysteriously trailing off into "We'll see." A vague, meaningless expression, but one often laced with menace or allusions to a threat (frequently involving tariffs and messing up another country's economy), that does nothing but create fear and uncertainty.

text: I live in Dubuque, Iowa and our airport travels only to Chicago. There were plans to build a railway between the two cities, but the problem came up for who would pay for it. A train that could travel directly between the two cities would really only benefit Dubuque and Iowa, but it would have to be built almost entirely through Illinois. The two states couldn't agree on a spending budget, and the project has been put on hold. I love the idea of more train travel, but the Federal government is going to have to give incentives for the states it travels through.

¬†@S Thomas¬† The earth's magnetic field does protect us from the sun's harmful UV rays, without it we'd be as barren as Mars who's atmosphere has been stripped away by the sun because it has no magnetic field.

But the aurora borealis is not the same as the magnetic field, the aurora borealis is the phenomenon of colourful glows around the poles of the magnetic field caused by interactions of the magnetic field and the sun's radiation. The aurora borealis doesn't protect us from anything, it just looks pretty on a long arctic night.

author: Chris Fox

text:
¬†@Chris Fox¬†  The Green New Deal is meant to be overly ambitious. The reason it greatly overshoots, well, realism is that with all proposals like this the time frame always causes those meant to implement it to drag their feet. 

"Well... It doesn't need to be done for another 10 years," they'll say, as they get massively behind schedule,  "that's two whole presidential elections. Who knows what the next government will think of this?"

So yeah, the Green New Deal is basically setting the bar really high so that if we only get a third of the way towards implementing it, that will still be enough to affect meaningful change, instead of setting the bar at the bare minimum needed to affect that change and watching as those goals aren't met.

"Mr. Cook‚Äôs work was quickly debunked. In Science and Education in August 2013, for example, David R. Legates (a professor of geography at the University of Delaware and former director of its Center for Climatic Research) and three coauthors reviewed the same papers as did Mr. Cook and found ‚Äúonly 41 papers‚Äî0.3 percent of all 11,944 abstracts or 1.0 percent of the 4,014 expressing an opinion, and not 97.1 percent‚Äîhad been found to endorse‚Äù the claim that human activity is causing most of the current warming. text: ¬†@Mr. Sarcastic¬†Not true, the bible is full of verses about having in excess and not helping your fellow man:  I tell you the truth, it is hard for a rich man to enter the kingdom of heaven. Again I tell you, it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God. When the disciples heard this, they were greatly astonished and asked, ‚ÄúWho then can be saved?‚Äù Jesus looked at them and said, ‚ÄúWith man this is impossible, but with God all things are possible.‚Äù Matthew 19:23-26  The saying was a response to a young rich man who had asked Jesus what he needed to do in order to inherit eternal life. Jesus replied that he should keep the commandments, to which the man stated he had done. Jesus responded, "If you want to be perfect, go, sell your possessions and give to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven. Then come, follow me." The young man became sad and was unwilling to do this. Jesus then spoke this response, leaving his disciples astonished.  The "Eye of the Needle" has been claimed to be a gate in Jerusalem, which opened after the main gate was closed at night. A camel could only pass through this smaller gate if it was stooped and had its baggage removed. This story has been put forth since at least the 15th century, and possibly as far back as the 9th century. However, there is no widely accepted evidence for the existence of such a gate.

text: The problem is not getting people to believe in climate change and want a change. The problem is convincing the WORLD, that‚Äôs right not America, the world, that there is a solution and that it will be affective and sustainable. There are a lot of smart scientists that believe in climate change but none that will say without a doubt what the solution is. Michigan climate professor says it could take 100 years before the world stops increasing temps and that‚Äôs if we ended all emissions today. Some scientists say the co2 in the atmosphere will never go away. Maybe the solution isn‚Äôt to produce less emissions but to somehow reclaim the emissions. The current solution of doing a nationwide regulation on emissions and try to reduce emissions with renewable energy is just a small step in the right direction and comes with major consequences to the economy and job market.. these things need to be thought out better and we shouldn‚Äôt just jump to the most rash decisions or we are cutting off our nose despite our face.

text:
¬†@KaraokeHammick¬† That's an understandable position. But most of what is advised in this space is one that is there to push innovation. It's fear mongering and wrong to say that legislating policies to benefit green technology development, will somehow push costs sky high. No one wants that (well, most - sure can dig out some hippy that does). 
The US government currently gives bucket loads of corporate welfare to fossil fuel companies. Trump is actively trying to stifle green incentives and push fossil fuel back to fore as a solution. If even a fraction of that was given to green, it would be possible to become a market leader.
We can't predict the future, but we can take good guesses. 
- Fossil fuels will run out, that is guaranteed. 
- If get Fusion, we can potentially synthesis fuels, to then use fossil infrastructure. But all of the infrastructure for renewables, works better and is more effective with fusion, then combustion. So even if hope get fusion and that'll solve issues, renewable still wise investment.
- Rest of the world believes in climate change, that is a very large market to sell stuff to...

They say next 17 years as a no going back tipping point. I believe, If we sit about doing nothing, and does turn out climate change is an issue, and we're past that tipping point. Even at worse case, then we can still fix it, so long as we haven't polluted LEO and stuck here with Kessler effect, then we can mine the belt and build shades out at the L1 point.
But... It doesn't hurt to give progress to better systems a nudge, and encourage it through legislation. We've got about as far as we can technologically burning stuff for energy, where as other methods have way more long term potential.

text:
¬†@Hornswogglefu¬† I'd review your history if I were you. When Hitler became Chancellor the Nazi party got 43.9% of the vote, which is decidedly less than half the country. They came to power because Germany employs a system of proportional representation, rather than a voting system like that if the US. Hitler and his party then took advantage of a clause in the German constitution called the Enabling Act, which essentially meant that if a majority of the parties voted with him, he could basically declare a national emergency, seize control of the various branches of government, and become a de facto dictator. Because of various issues at the time (many of which were caused by the Nazi party in order to establish that there was an emergency), the parties voted in Hitler's favour, he got what he wanted, and the Nazi rise to power was complete. 

Imagine that. A leader creating a false narrative to make people believe there is a national emergency, so that they can use the situation to seize power and/or get what they want. I wonder which 45th President of the United States could be doing that as we speak? Hmmmmm ü§î

text:
¬†@Josiah Kaminski¬† That isn't science. Science is supported through expirements not computer models. 
The fact you can add more variables still means it's not settled science. It's estimation and it's not precise. Which is why Curry pointed out in her most recent peer reviewed paper that observed warming is not consistent with the models projections and that ECS (estimated climate sensitivity) is overestimated.
author: jar josh

text: ¬†@jar josh¬† it is still more of an emergency than the imaginary one at our southern border. I really hope it's slower than predicted, that means more time to find solutions, but no; climate change deniers just use it as an excuse to continue ignoring science in the name of ignorance or profit. One data point that contradicts the rest of the sound data points does not nullify them, it adds variables that need to be taken into account. No computer model is 100% accurate, but conservative estimates are still fucking scary for the survival of our species into the next century. It's way easier to naysay than to get on board with the logical voting sequence that will bring about real change.
author: Josiah Kaminski
